The variance can be calculated for each lottery using the formula for variance of a discrete random variable: \( \text{Variance} = \sum (x_i - \mu)^2 \cdot p_i \), where \( x_i \) is each outcome, \( \mu \) is the mean of the outcomes, and \( p_i \) is the probability of each outcome. The mean for Lottery A is \( (-6000 \cdot 0.25) + (0 \cdot 0.75) = -1500 \) Euros, and for Lottery B, it's \( (-4000 \cdot 0.25) + (-2000 \cdot 0.25) + (0 \cdot 0.5) = -1500 \) Euros as well. - For Lottery B: \( \text{Variance} = ((-4000 - (-1500))^2 \cdot 0.25) + ((-2000 - (-1500))^2 \cdot 0.25) + ((0 - (-1500))^2 \cdot 0.5) = (-2500)^2 \cdot 0.25 + (-500)^2 \cdot 0.25 + (1500)^2 \cdot 0.5 \)

- For Lottery A: \( \text{Variance} = 20250000 \cdot 0.25 + 2250000 \cdot 0.75 = 5062500 + 1687500 = 6750000 \)
- For Lottery B: \( \text{Variance} = 6250000 \cdot 0.25 + 250000 \cdot 0.25 + 2250000 \cdot 0.5 = 1562500 + 62500 + 1125000 = 2750000 \)
